This is one of the games you play once, complete it fully, never play it again, yet you feel the money was well spent. Portal, doesn‚Äôt the name just imply that the game is something special? Portal is probably one of my favourite games, not only because of its originality and fun game design, but also since it‚Äôs so well made also for the speed running community.

[h1]Preface[/h1]
I first got this game on Xbox 360 something around 7 - 8 years ago. It was after I saw a YouTuber play this game on a video. I quickly fell in love. I completed the whole game in about an hour or two. Being a PC gamer it probably took longer because I wasn‚Äôt used to the controller. But never the less, great game and it stuck to me instantaneously. I then proceeded buying Portal 2 on Steam, and then this game one again, this time on Steam. Now let me show you why I think this game should be in your library, and what really defines this game.

[h1]The Review[/h1]
So this review will as my other reviews, be split into 3 main parts. These parts are Gameplay, Replayability and Speedrun. I have to say, always doing 3 main parts shouldn‚Äôt be too hard, but for this game, I could only think about Gameplay and Speedrun, but I do still have to touch on the Replayability part as that could be something people would want to know about.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
So the gameplay is pretty straight forward. You start in this room, having just woken up, it‚Äôs futuristic, you hear a radio, and suddenly a female robot start speaking. After about a minute, a portal suddenly open, and the puzzles begin. Yes, the game is a puzzle game, and it involves portals. The game brings you though 18 chambers, which leads you to the 19th chamber, which does involve a twist around finally getting what you long awaited for, Cake.

[b]Replayability[/b]
Now as I said, I didn‚Äôt expect to add this, but always going with 3 parts, this had to be it. I have to say, this isn‚Äôt the type of game you do play again because it feels like a fresh start. And the game is over in around 1 hour or 2 if you‚Äôre playing it slow. But it does still add up to the expectation. Remember, this game is mostly a prototype in the end, and judging by its price label, I don‚Äôt think it really matters that much in the end anyway.

[b]Speedrun[/b]
So this is one of the key parts of this game, speed running. Now if you do get into it, search up source runs, they have an older client used for most speed run records. But that aside, speed running is what gave me most 95% of my hours in this game. While it might not seem that interesting, if you‚Äôre into this type of gameplay, using the source runs version of this game, this is probably one of the more entertaining games for this kind. This is mostly because of how glitchy the game is at that stage, allowing you to find improvements in your runs literally anywhere you can imagine. The best time performed by a human, is nowhere near the time performed by a TAS bot (TAS = Tool Assisted Speedrun), which is a big deal compared to other games having speedruns of this form.

[h1]Is this game worth it?[/h1]
I‚Äôd say yes. Now don‚Äôt get me wrong, while this might not seem like a game that lives up to todays standards, it does play a big role in the history of gaming. I don‚Äôt think this would be a game of the year winning title, but I do think that it‚Äôs one of the games you should have played at least once, and if you‚Äôre planning on playing Portal 2, I strongly recommend starting at this one. And together with the game being around 9‚Ç¨, I don‚Äôt think the price tag is that much of an obstacle anyway, and do you have a penny over, this is definitely a game you should pick up if you haven‚Äôt already.
